- A second cloture motion on the motion to proceed to the bill was not invoked by a yea-nay vote (47–52).
- A third cloture motion was also not invoked by a yea-nay vote (47–50).
- A motion to reconsider the vote by which the second cloture was not invoked was agreed to by voice vote.

However, the provided vote records (47–52 and 47–50) indicate that the votes were not party-line in nature, as they involved a range of senators from both parties. The vote totals (47–52 and 47–50) suggest a bipartisan nature, with a majority of votes coming from both parties, though no explicit party-line designation is given in the records.

answers.1:
This bill, titled the *Continuing Appropriations and Extensions and Other Matters Act, 2026*, provides continuing appropriations for federal agencies through the earlier of October 31, 2025, or the enactment of the applicable appropriations act, preventing a government shutdown. It funds most programs at FY2025 levels with exceptions, including additional funding for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and security for federal officials.

The bill permanently extends the expanded premium tax credit for health insurance purchases, repeals certain health care provisions from the One Big Beautiful Bill Act (including those reducing Medicaid funding), authorizes the District of Columbia to spend local funds at FY2026 budget rates, extends funds withheld by OMB, and limits OMB's authority to withhold appropriations. It also extends several expiring programs and authorities in health care, veterans, homeland security, and agriculture.

The bill is in the Senate and was introduced as Senate Bill 2882. It is a continuing resolution (CR) and is part of the FY2026 appropriations process.

answers.1:
This bill, known as the Government Shutdown Prevention Act of 2025, provides automatic continuing appropriations at 94% of the previous fiscal year's funding level for an initial 90-day period to prevent a government shutdown. After that, the funding is reduced by 1% every subsequent 90-day period until regular appropriations legislation is enacted.

The bill is in the process of being introduced in the Senate and is currently in the Senate Appropriations Committee.

This bill, the Full-Year Continuing Appropriations and Extensions Act, 2025 (H.R. 1968), provides for full-year continuing appropriations to fund federal agencies and extends certain programs, ensuring federal operations continue without interruption during the 2025 fiscal year. It also includes provisions for specific program extensions and funding adjustments.

The bill is currently in the House of Representatives and has been referred to the House Budget Committee and the House Appropriations Committee for further review and consideration. It has no cosponsors listed and is not yet passed into law. The bill was introduced in the 119th Congress and is part of the legislative process for fiscal year 2025 appropriations. 

It was enacted as Public Law 119-4.
